Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Bone tumour arising from metaphysis? Options: A) Osteogenic sarcoma B) Ewing sarcoma C) Osteoclastoma D) Osteiod osteoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. is 'a' i.e., Osteogenic sarcomaMetaphvseal lesions Diaphyseal lesions o Osteogenic sarcoma o Ewing sarcomao Unicameral (simple) bone cyst o Lymphomaso Aneurysmal bone cyst o Fibrous dysplasiao Fibrous coical defect o AdamantinomaHistiocytosisOsteoid osteoma Therefore, the correct answer is A) Osteogenic sarcoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Russell’s body is found in: Options: A) Metastatic calcification B) Plasma cells C) RBC D) Mast cells<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Plasma cells.

Russell bodies are a type of inclusion body that is found in plasma cells, particularly in Waldenström's macroglobulinemia, a type of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. They are composed of immunoglobulin and are a characteristic feature of this disease.

Metastatic calcification (Option A) is a condition where calcium deposits form in tissues due to an imbalance of calcium and phosphorus levels in the blood.

Red blood cells (Option C) do not typically contain Russell bodies.

Mast cells (Option D) are a type of immune cell that is involved in allergic reactions, but they do not typically contain Russell bodies.<|eot_id|>
question: Question: Russell’s body is found in: Options: A) Metastatic calcification B) Plasma cells C) RBC D) Mast cells

Question: Non seminal germ cell tumors of testis secrete - Options: A) CEA B) Acid phosphatase C) Alfa feto protein D) Cytokeratin<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis, such as embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, and choriocarcinoma, can produce alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). AFP is a glycoprotein that is normally produced by the yolk sac during fetal development. Elevated levels of AFP in the blood can be used as a tumor marker to monitor the response to treatment and detect recurrence of the disease.

Seminoma, on the other hand, is a type of germ cell tumor that produces beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen) is not typically produced by testicular tumors.

Acid phosphatase is an enzyme that is often used as a marker for prostate cancer, not testicular cancer.

Cytokeratin is a protein that is found in the cytoskeleton of epithelial cells and is not typically used as a tumor marker for testicular cancer.<|eot_id|>
question: Question: Non seminal germ cell tumors of testis secrete - Options: A) CEA B) Acid phosphatase C) Alfa feto protein D) Cytokeratin

Question: Phagocytosis is the function of- Options: A) Astrocytes B) Oligodendrocytes C) Microglia D) Schawan cells<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Microglia.

Microglia are a type of glial cell that is responsible for phagocytosis, which is the process of engulfing and digesting foreign particles, dead cells, and cellular debris. They are the resident macrophages of the central nervous system (CNS) and play a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the CNS by removing pathogens, dead cells, and other foreign substances.

Astrocytes (Option A) are a type of glial cell that provides structural and metabolic support to neurons, but they do not have phagocytic activity.

Oligodendrocytes (Option B) are a type of glial cell that produces the myelin sheath around axons, but they do not have phagocytic activity.

Schwann cells (Option D) are a type of glial cell that produces the myelin sheath around peripheral nerves, but they do not have phagocytic activity.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which drug is used for topical application in respiratory papillomatosis? Options: A) Acyclovir B) Ranitidine C) Cidofovir D) Ribavirin<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Cidofovir.

Cidofovir is an antiviral medication that is used topically to treat respiratory papillomatosis, a condition characterized by the growth of papillomas (benign tumors) in the respiratory tract, typically caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is applied directly to the affected area using a spray or gel.

Acyclovir is an antiviral medication used to treat herpes simplex virus infections, such as cold sores and genital herpes.

Ranitidine is an antacid medication used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and other conditions.

Ribavirin is an antiviral medication used to treat hepatitis C and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Cidofovir.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A baby's blood group was determined as 0 Rh negative. Select the blood group the baby's mother or father will not have - Options: A) A, Rh Positive B) B, Rh Positive C) AB, Rh Negative D) O,Rh positive<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) O, Rh positive.

The baby's blood type is O Rh negative, which means they do not have the A or B antigens on their red blood cells and are also Rh negative.

The possible genotypes of the parents are:

* Mother: Oo or Oo (both parents can be Oo, or one parent can be Oo and the other parent can be Oo)
* Father: Oo or Ao or Bo or Ab (the father can be Oo, Ao, Bo, or Ab)

Since the baby is O Rh negative, the mother cannot be Rh positive (Rh+), as the Rh antigen would have been inherited from the father. Therefore, the correct answer is D) O, Rh positive.<|eot_id|>

Question: A patient with which of the follwing disease is predisposed to develop osteosarcoma -a)  Osteomalaciab)  Osteomyelitisc)  Paget's disease of boned)  Osteopetrosis Options: A) a B) c C) bc D) ad<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) bc

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically affects children and young adults. The risk factors for developing osteosarcoma include:

* Paget's disease of bone: Paget's disease is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, which can increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma.
* Osteochondromas: Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that can increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma.

Osteomalacia (option A) is a condition characterized by softening of the bones due to a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphorus. While it can cause bone pain and weakness, it is not a risk factor for osteosarcoma.

Osteomyelitis (option B) is an infection of the bone that can cause bone pain, swelling, and fever. While it can lead to bone destruction and deformity, it is not a risk factor for osteosarcoma.

Osteopetrosis (option D) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormal bone development and increased bone density. While it can cause bone pain and anemia, it is not a risk factor for osteosarcoma.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) bc, as both Paget's disease of bone and osteochondromas are risk factors for developing osteosarcoma.<|eot_id|>

Question: Chance of affected child to Autosomal recessive carrier parents is? Options: A) 10% B) 15% C) 25% D) 50%<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) 25%.

In autosomal recessive inheritance, the probability of an affected child is 25% when both parents are carriers of the recessive allele. This is because each parent has a 50% chance of passing on the recessive allele to their offspring, and the offspring must inherit two copies of the recessive allele (one from each parent) to express the condition.

So, the probability of an affected child is:

* 50% chance of inheriting the recessive allele from one parent
* 50% chance of inheriting the recessive allele from the other parent
* 25% chance of inheriting two recessive alleles (one from each parent) and being affected

Therefore, the correct answer is C) 25%.<|eot_id|>

Question: Shock lung is seen in? Options: A) Bronchiectasis B) Lung carcinoma C) ARDS D) COPD<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome).

Shock lung, also known as adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is a life-threatening condition characterized by inflammation and damage to the lungs, leading to respiratory failure. It is often caused by severe trauma, sepsis, pneumonia, or other systemic illnesses. The lungs become stiff and leaky, leading to low oxygen levels in the blood and difficulty breathing.

Bronchiectasis (Option A) is a chronic condition characterized by permanent damage to the airways, leading to chronic coughing and wheezing.

Lung carcinoma (Option B) is a type of cancer that can cause respiratory symptoms, but it is not typically associated with shock lung.

COPD (Option D) is a chronic condition characterized by chronic bronchitis and emphysema, which can cause respiratory symptoms, but it is not typically associated with shock lung.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Intake of which of these cause vascular lesions in liver - Options: A) Halothanes B) INH C) Steroids D) CPZ<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Steroids.

Steroids can cause a range of vascular lesions in the liver, including:

* Peliosis hepatis: a rare condition characterized by the formation of blood-filled cysts in the liver
* Hepatic sinusoidal dilatation: a condition characterized by dilation of the hepatic sinusoids
* Hepatic veno-occlusive disease: a condition characterized by obstruction of the hepatic veins

Halothane (A) can cause a rare condition called halothane hepatitis, which is an allergic reaction to the anesthetic agent.

INH (B) can cause a range of liver damage, including hepatitis and cirrhosis, but it is not typically associated with vascular lesions.

CPZ (D) is an antipsychotic medication that can cause liver damage, including hepatitis and cholestasis, but it is not typically associated with vascular lesions.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Steroids.<|eot_id|>

Question: Schiller - Duval bodies are seen in- Options: A) Teratoma B) Seminoma C) Yolk sac tumour D) Chorio - carcinoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Yolk sac tumour.

Schiller-Duval bodies are a characteristic histopathological feature of yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors) of the testis or ovary. They are small, rounded, and PAS-positive structures that contain alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and are thought to represent the remnants of the yolk sac.

Teratoma (Option A) is a type of germ cell tumor that contains elements from two or more germ layers, but it does not typically contain Schiller-Duval bodies.

Seminoma (Option B) is a type of germ cell tumor that arises from the seminiferous tubules of the testis and is typically composed of uniform, large, and polygonal cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio.

Choriocarcinoma (Option D) is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease that arises from the placenta and is characterized by the presence of syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts. It does not typically contain Schiller-Duval bodies.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which of the following is not a major criteria for diagnosis of multiple myeloma? Options: A) Lytic bone lesions B) Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy C) Bone marrow plasmacytosis > 30% D) `M' spike > 3g% for 1g G, > 2g% for IgA<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy.

The International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) defines the following criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma:

1. **Major criteria**:
	* Bone marrow plasmacytosis > 30%
	* Monoclonal protein in the serum or urine (M-spike)
	* Lytic bone lesions
	* Plasmacytoma on imaging studies (e.g., MRI, CT, or PET)
2. **Minor criteria**:
	* Plasmacytosis 10-30% in the bone marrow
	* Monoclonal protein in the serum or urine (M-spike) < 3g/dL for IgG, < 2g/dL for IgA
	* Abnormal free light chain ratio
	* Abnormal bone marrow biopsy with plasma cells

Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy is not a major criterion for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Instead, it is a characteristic feature of solitary plasmacytoma, which is a distinct entity from multiple myeloma.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Plasmacytoma on tissue biopsy.<|eot_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which of the following is not a minor diagnositic criteria for multiple myeloma? Options: A) Lytic bone lesions B) Plasmacytosis greater than 20% C) Plasmacytoma on biopsy D) Monoclonal globuline spike on serum electrophoresis of> 2.5 g/dl for IgG, > 1.5 g/dl for IgA<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Plasmacytoma on biopsy.

The minor diagnostic criteria for multiple myeloma are:

* Lytic bone lesions
* Plasmacytosis greater than 20% on bone marrow examination
* Monoclonal globulin spike on serum electrophoresis of > 2.5 g/dl for IgG, > 1.5 g/dl for IgA

A plasmacytoma is a solitary tumor composed of plasma cells, and it is not a minor diagnostic criterion for multiple myeloma. In fact, the presence of a solitary plasmacytoma is often considered a distinct entity from multiple myeloma.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Plasmacytoma on biopsy.<|eot_id|>

Question: CD 34 is a tumor marker used for - Options: A) Ewings sarcoma B) Myofibrosarcoma C) Alveolar soft part sarcoma D) Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Alveolar soft part sarcoma.

CD34 is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is expressed on the surface of hematopoietic progenitor cells, endothelial cells, and some sarcomas. It is a useful marker for the diagnosis of alveolar soft part sarcoma (ASPS), a rare type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically affects young adults. CD34 is expressed in the majority of ASPS cases, making it a useful marker for distinguishing this tumor from other soft tissue sarcomas.

CD34 is not typically expressed in Ewing's sarcoma, myofibrosarcoma, or inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor, so these options are not correct.<|eot_id|>

Question: Ferruginous bodies are seen in - Options: A) Silicosis B) Bysinosis C) Asbestosis D) Baggassosis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Asbestosis.

Ferruginous bodies are also known as asbestos bodies or asbestos fibers. They are a type of mineral fiber that is found in the lungs of individuals who have been exposed to asbestos. They are typically 5-20 micrometers in length and are composed of iron oxide and other minerals. Ferruginous bodies are a hallmark of asbestos-related disease and are often seen in individuals with asbestosis, a chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers.

Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica particles, and is characterized by the formation of nodules in the lungs.

Bysinosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling cotton dust, and is characterized by the formation of nodules in the lungs.

Baggassosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling bagasse, a type of sugarcane residue, and is characterized by the formation of nodules in the lungs.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Asbestosis.<|eot_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Question: Generalized body edema is associated with deficiency of? Options: A) Vitamin B12 B) Sodium C) Albumin D) EFAs<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Albumin.

Generalized body edema is a common manifestation of hypoalbuminemia, which is a deficiency of albumin in the blood. Albumin is the main protein component of blood plasma and plays a crucial role in maintaining blood volume and blood pressure. When albumin levels are low, fluid leaks out of the blood vessels and into the tissues, leading to edema.

Vitamin B12 deficiency is not typically associated with generalized body edema. Sodium is an electrolyte that helps regulate fluid balance in the body, but its deficiency is not typically associated with generalized edema. Essential fatty acids (EFAs) are important for various bodily functions, but their deficiency is not typically associated with generalized edema.

Hypoalbuminemia can be caused by a variety of factors, including liver disease, kidney disease, malnutrition, and certain medications. Treatment of hypoalbuminemia typically involves addressing the underlying cause and managing symptoms such as edema with diuretics and fluid restriction.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which of the following mutation is seen in Cowden syndrome? Options: A) STK 11 mutation B) SMAD 4 mutation C) PTEN mutation D) PTCH mutation<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) PTEN mutation.

Cowden syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple hamartomas, including those in the skin, breast, and thyroid, as well as an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancer. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homologue) gene, which is a tumor suppressor gene.

STK11 (Serine/Threonine Kinase 11) is a gene associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and mucocutaneous pigmentation.

SMAD4 (Mothers Against Decapentaplegic Homolog 4) is a gene associated with Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple juvenile polyps in the gastrointestinal tract.

PTCH (Patched) is a gene associated with Gorlin syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple basal cell carcinomas and other skin lesions.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) PTEN mutation.<|eot_id|>

Question: Mycosis fungoides is: Options: A) Fungal infections of skin B) Leukemia C) Exfoliative erythroderma D) Cutaneous lymphoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Cutaneous lymphoma.

Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous lymphoma, also known as primary cutaneous lymphoma, which is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that affects the skin. It is a chronic and progressive disease characterized by the proliferation of malignant T-cells in the skin, leading to the formation of patches, plaques, and tumors.

The other options are not correct:

A) Fungal infections of the skin are typically caused by fungi such as dermatophytes, candida, or aspergillus, and are not related to mycosis fungoides.

B) Leukemia is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, and is not directly related to mycosis fungoides.

C) Exfoliative erythroderma is a skin condition characterized by widespread scaling and erythema, but it is not a type of lymphoma.<|eot_id|>

Question: Alzheimer's disease associated chromosome is Options: A) 2 B) 6 C) 12 D) 19<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) 19.

Alzheimer's disease is associated with mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene, which is located on chromosome 19. The APP gene is responsible for encoding the amyloid precursor protein, which is a protein that is involved in the formation of the beta-amyloid plaques that are a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

The APP gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 19 (19q13.2) and is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in the APP gene can cause early-onset Alzheimer's disease, which is characterized by the onset of symptoms before the age of 65.

It's worth noting that while chromosome 19 is the most commonly associated with Alzheimer's disease, other chromosomes, such as chromosomes 1, 14, and 21, have also been linked to the disease.<|eot_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: The following karyotype in female is seen in which of the following syndromes? Options: A) Bloom syndrome B) Fragile X syndrome C) Angelman syndrome D) Cri du chat syndrome<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Cri du chat syndrome.

Cri du chat syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deletion of part of the short arm of chromosome 5. The karyotype in females with Cri du chat syndrome is typically 46,X,del(5p), meaning they have a deletion of the short arm of one X chromosome.

Bloom syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the BLM gene on chromosome 15. The karyotype in Bloom syndrome is typically 46,XY or 46,X, but there is no deletion of a specific chromosome arm.

Fragile X syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by an expansion of a CGG repeat in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. The karyotype in Fragile X syndrome is typically 46,X, but there is no deletion of a specific chromosome arm.

Angelman syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15. The karyotype in Angelman syndrome is typically 46,XY or 46,X, but there is no deletion of a specific chromosome arm.<|eot_id|>

Question: With regard to the malignant behavior of leiomyosarcoma, the most impoant criterion is Options: A) Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells B) Tumor cells in lymphatic channels C) Lymphocyte infiltration D) The number of mitoses per high power field<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) The number of mitoses per high power field.

Leiomyosarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that arises from smooth muscle cells. The malignant behavior of leiomyosarcoma is characterized by its ability to invade surrounding tissues and metastasize to distant sites. The most important criterion for predicting the malignant behavior of leiomyosarcoma is the number of mitoses per high power field (HPF).

The World Health Organization (WHO) criteria for diagnosing leiomyosarcoma include:

* The presence of at least 10 mitoses per 10 HPF in the most mitotically active area of the tumor
* The presence of at least 5 mitoses per 10 HPF in the most mitotically active area of the tumor, along with other features of malignancy such as tumor necrosis, infiltrative margins, or lymphatic invasion

The other options are not accurate criteria for predicting the malignant behavior of leiomyosarcoma:

* A) Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells is a feature of many types of cancer, but it is not a specific criterion for leiomyosarcoma.
* B) Tumor cells in lymphatic channels are not a specific criterion for leiomyosarcoma, and lymphatic invasion is not a reliable predictor of malignant behavior.
* C) Lymphocyte infiltration is a feature of many types of cancer, including leiomyosarcoma, but it is not a specific criterion for predicting malignant behavior.<|eot_id|>

Question: The kebab treatment is used for treatment of which of the following conditions Options: A) Paget's disease B) Osteoahritis C) Myositis ossificans D) Osteogenesis imperfecta<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Paget's disease.

The "kebab treatment" is a colloquial term for a treatment for Paget's disease, which involves injecting a sclerosant agent into the affected bone to reduce the size of the bone and relieve symptoms. The term "kebab" is thought to have originated from the appearance of the treated bone, which resembles a kebab or a skewer.

Paget's disease is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlargement and deformity of the affected bones. The kebab treatment is a minimally invasive procedure that is used to treat the condition, particularly in cases where other treatments have failed.

The other options are not correct because:

* Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease that is treated with medications, physical therapy, and joint replacement surgery.
* Myositis ossificans is a condition in which muscle tissue is replaced with bone, and it is typically treated with physical therapy and pain management.
* Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder that affects bone development and is treated with medications, physical therapy, and orthotics.<|eot_id|>

Question: Burning Mouth Syndrome describes pain associated with Options: A) Oral lichen planus B) Oral submucous fibrosis C) Aphthous stomatitis D) No detectable oral disease<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) No detectable oral disease.

Burning Mouth Syndrome (BMS) is a chronic condition characterized by a burning sensation in the mouth, tongue, and lips, often accompanied by other symptoms such as dryness, numbness, and tingling. Despite thorough examination and investigation, no underlying oral disease or lesion is found. The exact cause of BMS is unknown, but it is thought to be related to hormonal changes, nutritional deficiencies, and psychological factors.

Oral lichen planus (Option A) is a chronic inflammatory condition that can cause pain, but it is typically characterized by characteristic lesions on the mucous membranes.

Oral submucous fibrosis (Option B) is a condition that can cause pain, but it is characterized by fibrosis and stiffness of the mucous membranes, which is not typical of BMS.

Aphthous stomatitis (Option C) is a condition that causes painful ulcers in the mouth, but it is typically characterized by the presence of ulcers, which is not typical of BMS.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Major contribution to cachexia with advanced cancer? Options: A) Clathrin B) Histamine C) Interferon D) Tumor-necrosis-factor (TNT)<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Tumor-necrosis-factor (TNF).

Cachexia is a complex metabolic syndrome characterized by weight loss, muscle wasting, and loss of body mass, which is a common complication of advanced cancer. Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) is a cytokine that plays a key role in the development of cachexia in cancer patients. TNF-alpha is produced by tumor cells and immune cells in response to tumor growth and inflammation, and it can induce muscle wasting and weight loss by inhibiting protein synthesis and increasing protein degradation.

Clathrin is a protein involved in endocytosis and is not directly related to cachexia.

Histamine is a neurotransmitter involved in allergic reactions and is not a major contributor to cachexia.

Interferon is a cytokine that has antiviral and antiproliferative effects, but it is not a major contributor to cachexia.

Therefore, the correct answer is D) Tumor-necrosis-factor (TNF).<|eot_id|>

Question: Which of the following is a ourable prognostic factor in a case of neuroblastoma? Options: A) Diploidy B) N-myc amplification C) Chromosome / p depletion D) Trk A expression<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. D) Trk A expression

TrkA (tropomyosin-related kinase A) is a receptor tyrosine kinase that is involved in the development and survival of neurons. TrkA expression is a favorable prognostic factor in neuroblastoma, as it is associated with a better overall survival and event-free survival.

Diploidy (having two sets of chromosomes) is a poor prognostic factor in neuroblastoma, as it is associated with a worse outcome.

N-myc amplification is a poor prognostic factor in neuroblastoma, as it is associated with a worse overall survival and event-free survival.

Chromosome 1p deletion is a poor prognostic factor in neuroblastoma, as it is associated with a worse overall survival and event-free survival.

Therefore, the correct answer is D) Trk A expression.<|eot_id|>

Question: First change seen in acute inflammation is: September 2009 Options: A) Increased permeability B) Vasodilation C) Neutrophil migration D) Vasoconstriction<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Vasoconstriction.

The sequence of events in acute inflammation is:

1. Vasoconstriction: The first response to injury is vasoconstriction, which reduces blood flow to the affected area.
2. Vasodilation: As the inflammatory response progresses, vasodilation occurs, increasing blood flow to the affected area.
3. Increased permeability: The blood vessels become more permeable, allowing fluid and proteins to leak out into the tissue.
4. Neutrophil migration: Neutrophils migrate into the tissue in response to chemotactic factors.
5. Phagocytosis: Neutrophils engulf and digest foreign particles and bacteria.

So, the correct answer is D) Vasoconstriction, which is the first change seen in acute inflammation.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which of the following is not associated with pathological apoptosis? Options: A) DNA damage B) ER stress C) Transplant rejection D) Involution of hormone dependent tissue upon hormone withdrawal<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Transplant rejection.

Pathological apoptosis is a type of programmed cell death that occurs in response to various cellular stresses, including:

* DNA damage (A)
* Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress (B)
* Hormone withdrawal, such as the involution of hormone-dependent tissues (D)

Transplant rejection, on the other hand, is an immune response that occurs when the body recognizes a transplanted organ or tissue as foreign and attacks it. It is not a type of programmed cell death, but rather an immune response that can lead to tissue damage and rejection.

Therefore, the correct answer is C) Transplant rejection.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: In Huntington chorea the causative mutation in the protein huntingtin is a: Options: A) Point mutation B) Gene deletion C) Frameshift mutation D) Trinucleotide repeat expansion<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Trinucleotide repeat expansion.

Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by an expansion of a CAG repeat in the Huntingtin gene. This expansion leads to an abnormally long polyglutamine tract in the Huntingtin protein, which is toxic to neurons and leads to the characteristic symptoms of the disease.

The CAG repeat expansion is a type of trinucleotide repeat expansion, which is a common mechanism of genetic instability that can lead to a range of neurodegenerative disorders.

Point mutations (A) are changes in a single nucleotide, gene deletions (B) are the loss of a segment of DNA, and frameshift mutations (C) are changes that alter the reading frame of the genetic code, but trinucleotide repeat expansions are a distinct type of mutation that involves the expansion of a specific sequence of nucleotides.<|eot_id|>

Question: Type I hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by: Options: A) IgG B) IgM C) IgD D) IgE<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) IgE.

Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE antibodies, which are produced by B cells in response to an allergen. IgE antibodies bind to the surface of mast cells and basophils, leading to the release of chemical mediators such as histamine, which causes symptoms such as itching, hives, and anaphylaxis.

IgG and IgM antibodies are involved in type II and type III hypersensitivity reactions, respectively, which are different types of immune responses.

IgD is an antibody that is found on the surface of mature B cells and plays a role in the activation of B cells, but it is not directly involved in type I hypersensitivity reactions.

Therefore, the correct answer is D) IgE.<|eot_id|>

Question: CD marker of Angiosarcoma is? Options: A) CD 10 B) CD 19 C) CD 25 D) CD 31<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) CD 31.

Angiosarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that arises from the blood vessels. It is characterized by the presence of CD31, a marker of endothelial cells. CD31 is a transmembrane glycoprotein that is expressed on the surface of endothelial cells and is involved in cell adhesion and signaling.

CD31 is a sensitive and specific marker for angiosarcoma, and its expression is typically strong and diffuse in these tumors. Other markers that may be expressed in angiosarcoma include CD34, CD105, and factor VIII, but CD31 is the most specific and sensitive marker for this diagnosis.

The other options are not correct:

* CD10 is a marker for B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma and is not typically expressed in angiosarcoma.
* CD19 is a marker for B cells and is not typically expressed in angiosarcoma.
* CD25 is a marker for activated T cells and is not typically expressed in angiosarcoma.<|eot_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Vasoactive amine, involved in inflammation is - Options: A) dopamine B) adrenaline C) Angiotensin D) Histamine<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Histamine.

Histamine is a vasoactive amine that plays a key role in the inflammatory response. It is released from mast cells and basophils in response to allergic reactions, injury, or infection. Histamine causes blood vessels to dilate, leading to increased blood flow and swelling, and also causes smooth muscle contraction, leading to increased mucus production and bronchospasm.

Dopamine (A) is a neurotransmitter involved in various physiological processes, including movement, mood regulation, and hormone secretion. Adrenaline (B) is a hormone released by the adrenal glands in response to stress, which prepares the body for the "fight or flight" response. Angiotensin (C) is a peptide hormone involved in the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which regulates blood pressure and electrolyte balance.<|eot_id|>

Question: Macropolycyte in peripheral smear is a feature of- Options: A) Hereditary sherocytosis B) Iron deficiency anaemia C) Sickle cell anaemia D) Megaloblastic anaemia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Megaloblastic anaemia.

Macropolycytes are large, immature red blood cells that are characteristic of megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia is a type of anemia caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate, which impairs the production of red blood cells in the bone marrow. The resulting red blood cells are large, irregularly shaped, and have an abnormal nucleus, which is known as a macropolycyte.

Hereditary spherocytosis (Option A) is a condition characterized by the production of abnormally shaped red blood cells that are spherical rather than disk-shaped.

Iron deficiency anemia (Option B) is a condition characterized by a decrease in the production of hemoglobin in the red blood cells, leading to a decrease in the number of red blood cells and a decrease in the amount of oxygen carried by the blood.

Sickle cell anemia (Option C) is a genetic disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, leading to the formation of abnormal red blood cells that are crescent-shaped and have a reduced ability to carry oxygen.

Therefore, the correct answer is D) Megaloblastic anaemia.<|eot_id|>

Question: MOST common mutation seen in heriditary hemochromatosis is: Options: A) C282Y B) H63D C) TFR2 D) SLC11A3<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) C282Y.

Hereditary hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the HFE gene. The most common mutation is the C282Y mutation, which is found in approximately 80-90% of patients with hereditary hemochromatosis. This mutation leads to an accumulation of iron in the body, particularly in the liver, pancreas, and other organs, which can cause damage and lead to symptoms such as cirrhosis, liver failure, and arthritis.

H63D is another common mutation, but it is less common than C282Y and is often associated with a milder form of the disease. TFR2 and SLC11A3 are not typically associated with hereditary hemochromatosis.

It's worth noting that genetic testing for hereditary hemochromatosis typically involves testing for the C282Y and H63D mutations, as these are the most common and clinically relevant mutations.<|eot_id|>

Question: Histopathology of mitral Valve prolapsed shows what kind of change? Options: A) Myxomatous B) Fibrinoid C) Granulomatous D) Fibrous<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Myxomatous.

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a condition characterized by the abnormal relaxation of the mitral valve leaflets, leading to their prolapse into the left atrium during systole. Histopathologically, the valve leaflets show characteristic changes of myxomatous degeneration, which is characterized by:

* Increased production of glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans
* Disorganization of the normal collagen and elastin fibers
* Presence of mucoid material
* Enlargement of the valve leaflets

These changes lead to the formation of a thick, gelatinous, and fragile valve leaflet that is prone to prolapse. The myxomatous degeneration is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors, including hormonal influences and mechanical stress on the valve.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>
