Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 48-year-old woman complains she has had weakness, fatigue, and easy bruisability for 2 months. She had worked as a technician in a nuclear energy plant for 15 years and was involved in an accident during which she was exposed to considerable radiation. Physical examination reveals an enlarged liver and spleen. What disease should you suspect as a likely cause of her condition? Options: A) Chronic myelogenous leukemia B) Hairy cell leukemia C) Metastatic carcinoma of the breast D) Metastatic carcinoma of the stomach<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Chronic myelogenous leukemia.

The patient's symptoms of weakness, fatigue, and easy bruising, along with the physical examination findings of an enlarged liver and spleen, are consistent with a diagnosis of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). CML is a type of leukemia that is caused by a genetic mutation in the BCR-ABL1 gene, which is often associated with radiation exposure. The patient's history of working in a nuclear energy plant and being involved in an accident during which she was exposed to considerable radiation increases the likelihood of CML.

Hairy cell leukemia (B) is a type of chronic lymphocytic leukemia that is characterized by the presence of hairy cells in the blood and bone marrow. While it can cause fatigue and weakness, it is not typically associated with radiation exposure.

Metastatic carcinoma of the breast (D) or stomach (D) can cause symptoms such as weakness, fatigue, and easy bruising, but it would not typically cause an enlarged liver and spleen.

It's worth noting that the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are not specific to CML, and a definitive diagnosis would require further testing, such as a complete blood count, bone marrow biopsy, and genetic testing.<|eot_id|>

Question: Spot the diagnosis Options: A) Lead poisoning B) Macrocytic anemia C) Howell-Jolly bodies D) Heinz bodies<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is D) Heinz bodies.

Heinz bodies are small, round, and dark-staining structures that appear in the cytoplasm of red blood cells. They are composed of denatured hemoglobin and are a sign of oxidative stress and hemolytic anemia.

The other options are not correct:

A) Lead poisoning is a type of poisoning that can cause anemia, but it does not typically cause Heinz bodies.

B) Macrocytic anemia is a type of anemia characterized by large red blood cells, which is not related to Heinz bodies.

C) Howell-Jolly bodies are small, round, and dark-staining structures that appear in the cytoplasm of red blood cells, but they are not the same as Heinz bodies. Howell-Jolly bodies are a sign of bone marrow failure or splenectomy.<|eot_id|>

Question: Wilson's disease is? Options: A) AR B) AD C) XR D) XD<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) AR.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the ATP7B gene, which codes for the copper-transporting P-type ATPase. This gene is located on chromosome 13 and is responsible for the transport of copper out of the liver and into the bile. Mutations in this gene lead to the accumulation of copper in the liver and brain, causing the symptoms of Wilson's disease.<|eot_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Stains used in amyloidosis- Options: A) Congo red B) Thioflavin C) Reticulin D) Grams Iodine<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Congo red.

Congo red is a specific stain used to diagnose amyloidosis. It binds to the beta-pleated sheet structure of amyloid fibrils, causing them to stain pink or red. This is a characteristic feature of amyloidosis and is often used to distinguish it from other types of protein deposits.

Thioflavin (B) is a fluorescent dye that is used to stain amyloid deposits, but it is not as specific as Congo red.

Reticulin (C) is a stain used to highlight the reticulin fibers in the connective tissue, but it is not specific for amyloidosis.

Gram's iodine (D) is a stain used to detect fungal elements, and it is not relevant to the diagnosis of amyloidosis.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: The prognosis of rapidly proliferating glomerulonephritis (Crescentic GN) depends upon which of the following factor? Options: A) Number of crescents B) Size of crescents C) Shape of crescents D) Cellularity of crescents<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Number of crescents.

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is a type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis characterized by the formation of crescents, which are areas of proliferating cells and matrix that replace the normal glomerular architecture. The prognosis of crescentic glomerulonephritis is directly related to the number of crescents present. The more crescents present, the worse the prognosis.

The number of crescents is a strong predictor of the likelihood of progression to end-stage renal disease. Patients with fewer than 10% crescents have a good prognosis, while those with 10-50% crescents have a moderate prognosis, and those with more than 50% crescents have a poor prognosis.

The size, shape, and cellularity of the crescents are not as important predictors of prognosis as the number of crescents. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which of the following head and neck tumor has worst prognosis? Options: A) Adenoid cystic carcinoma B) Acinic cell carcinoma C) Cystadenolymphoma D) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. A) Adenoid cystic carcinomaAdenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) is a type of head and neck cancer that typically arises in the parotid gland, but can also occur in other salivary glands, such as the submandibular gland, sublingual gland, and minor salivary glands. It is a malignant tumor that is characterized by its tendency to recur locally and metastasize to regional lymph nodes and distant sites. ACC is known for its aggressive behavior and poor prognosis, with a 5-year survival rate of around 50%. It is also known for its tendency to recur locally, even after treatment, and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality.<|eot_id|>

Question: Podocytes are seen in - Options: A) Bowman's capsule B) Proximal convoluted tubule C) Distal convoluted tubule D) Collecting tubule of the kidney<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Bowman's capsule.

Podocytes are specialized epithelial cells that form the visceral layer of Bowman's capsule, which is the structure that surrounds the glomerulus in the kidney. They play a crucial role in the filtration of blood and the reabsorption of substances from the glomerular filtrate.

The other options are incorrect because:

* Proximal convoluted tubule (B) is a part of the nephron where reabsorption of water and solutes occurs.
* Distal convoluted tubule (C) is a part of the nephron where reabsorption of water and electrolytes occurs.
* Collecting tubule (D) is a part of the nephron where the final stage of urine formation occurs, and it is not associated with podocytes.<|eot_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the most common defectively produced antibody in multiple myeloma? Options: A) Ig G B) Ig M C) Ig A D) Ig D<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) IgG.

Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer that affects plasma cells, which are a type of white blood cell that produces antibodies. In multiple myeloma, the plasma cells produce abnormal antibodies, known as M proteins, which can accumulate in the blood and urine. The most common type of M protein produced in multiple myeloma is an IgG antibody, specifically an IgG kappa or IgG lambda antibody.

IgG is the most common immunoglobulin produced by plasma cells, and it is also the most common type of M protein produced in multiple myeloma. IgM and IgA are less commonly produced in multiple myeloma, and IgD is not typically produced at all.

Therefore, the correct answer is A) IgG.<|eot_id|>

Question: Flow cytometry is done to know - Options: A) Rapid cell shrinkage B) Blood flow to brain C) Net O2 supply to tissues D) Amount of O2 bound to hemoglobin<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Rapid cell shrinkage.

Flow cytometry is a laboratory technique used to measure the physical and chemical characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and surface markers. It is commonly used to:

* Identify and count specific cell populations, such as white blood cells, platelets, and red blood cells
* Analyze the expression of surface markers on cells, such as CD4 and CD8 on T cells
* Detect and quantify abnormal cells, such as cancer cells or cells infected with viruses
* Study the cell cycle and cell proliferation

Flow cytometry is not used to measure blood flow to the brain (B), net O2 supply to tissues (C), or the amount of O2 bound to hemoglobin (D). These are all related to hemodynamics and oxygenation, which are measured using different techniques, such as Doppler ultrasound, positron emission tomography (PET), and blood gas analysis.<|eot_id|>

Question: The aganglionic segment is encountered in which part of the colon in case of Hirschsprung disease - Options: A) Distal to dilated segment B) In Whole colon C) Proximal to dilated segment D) In the dilated segment<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Distal to dilated segment

Hirschsprung disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum and distal colon, leading to constipation and bowel obstruction. The aganglionic segment is the part of the colon that lacks ganglion cells and is typically located in the rectum and distal colon, distal to the dilated segment.

The dilated segment is the proximal part of the colon that is above the aganglionic segment and is characterized by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the smooth muscle and submucosa, leading to a dilated and hypertrophic colon.

Therefore, the aganglionic segment is encountered distal to the dilated segment in Hirschsprung disease.<|eot_id|>

Question: Pathology in achlasia cardia is? Options: A) Degeneration of nerves B) Muscular atrophy C) Hypertrophy of nerves D) Hypertrophy of muscles<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Degeneration of nerves.

Achalasia cardia is a motor disorder of the esophagus characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax and the absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body. The pathology of achalasia cardia is characterized by:

* Degeneration of the myenteric plexus, which is the nerve plexus that controls the muscles of the esophagus.
* Loss of ganglion cells, which are the nerve cells that transmit signals to the muscles of the esophagus.
* Fibrosis and inflammation in the esophageal wall.

There is no muscular atrophy (B) or hypertrophy (D) in achalasia cardia. The muscles of the esophagus are normal, but they are not functioning properly due to the degeneration of the nerves that control them.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which of the following shows crescent shaped deposits under light microscope? Options: A) RPGN B) Acute GN C) Membranous GN D) Membranoproliferative GN<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) RPGN (Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis).

Crescent-shaped deposits, also known as crescents, are a characteristic feature of RPGN. They are formed when the glomerular capillary walls are damaged and the podocytes and mesangial cells proliferate and differentiate into a crescent-shaped structure. This is a hallmark of RPGN, which is a severe and rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

The other options are not correct:

* Acute GN (Option B) typically shows diffuse glomerular damage with inflammation and proliferation of cells, but not crescent-shaped deposits.
* Membranous GN (Option C) is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes in the subepithelial space, leading to the formation of a membrane-like structure, but not crescent-shaped deposits.
* Membranoproliferative GN (Option D) is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes in the mesangium and subendothelial space, leading to the formation of a membrane-like structure, but not crescent-shaped deposits.<|eot_id|>

Question: Broncho-pneumonia due to measles occurs due to Options: A) Sinusitis B) Immuno modulation C) Bronchial obstruction D) Aspiration<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Immuno modulation.

Bronchopneumonia due to measles is a common complication of measles, especially in children. It is caused by the immunosuppressive effects of the measles virus, which impairs the immune system's ability to fight off secondary bacterial infections. The virus causes a decrease in the production of immunoglobulins, particularly IgG, which makes the child more susceptible to secondary bacterial infections, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus. These bacteria can colonize the lungs and cause bronchopneumonia.

Sinusitis (Option A) is not a direct cause of bronchopneumonia due to measles.

Bronchial obstruction (Option C) is not a primary cause of bronchopneumonia due to measles, although it can occur as a complication of the disease.

Aspiration (Option D) is not a direct cause of bronchopneumonia due to measles, although it can occur as a complication of the disease in some cases.<|eot_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Most common cause of death in primary am loidosis is? Options: A) Respiratory failure B) Cardiac failure C) Renal failure D) Septicemia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) Respiratory failure.

Primary amyloidosis, also known as AL amyloidosis, is a rare disorder characterized by the deposition of abnormal protein fibrils in various tissues and organs. The most common cause of death in primary amyloidosis is respiratory failure, which is often due to the deposition of amyloid fibrils in the lungs, leading to restrictive lung disease and respiratory failure. Other common causes of death in primary amyloidosis include cardiac failure, renal failure, and sepsis.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which of the following can recognize dead material? Options: A) NET B) Inflammasome C) Necrosis D) Toll-like receptor<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Inflammasome.

Inflammasomes are multi-protein complexes that recognize and respond to the presence of dead cells, damaged cells, and other forms of cellular stress. They play a crucial role in the activation of the innate immune response and the elimination of dead cells.

NETs (Neutrophil Extracellular Traps) are structures formed by neutrophils in response to bacterial infections, but they do not recognize dead material.

Necrosis is a type of cell death, but it is not a mechanism for recognizing dead material.

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a family of pattern recognition receptors that recognize specific molecular patterns associated with pathogens, such as bacterial lipopolysaccharides, but they do not recognize dead material.

Inflammasomes are a type of cytoplasmic pattern recognition receptor that recognizes and responds to the presence of dead cells, damaged cells, and other forms of cellular stress. They are composed of a protein called ASC (apoptosis-associated speck-like protein containing a CARD) and the pro-caspase-1 enzyme. When an inflammasome is activated, it cleaves pro-caspase-1 into its active form, which then cleaves the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1β into its active form, leading to the release of IL-1β and the activation of the immune response.<|eot_id|>

Question: The translocation seen in follicular lymphoma is Options: A) T(11,14) B) T(14,18) C) T(9,22) D) T(8,14)<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) T(14,18).

Follicular lymphoma is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is characterized by a translocation involving the immunoglobulin heavy chain gene (IGH) on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18. This translocation, known as t(14;18), results in the formation of a fusion protein that promotes the survival of cancer cells.

The other options are not correct:

* T(11;14) is a translocation seen in mantle cell lymphoma, not follicular lymphoma.
* T(9;22) is a translocation seen in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not follicular lymphoma.
* T(8;14) is a translocation seen in Burkitt lymphoma, not follicular lymphoma.<|eot_id|>

Question: Most common benign tumor of oesophagus is: Options: A) Lipoma B) Leiomyoma C) Hamartoma D) Hemangioma<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Leiomyoma.

Leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus, accounting for approximately 50-60% of all esophageal tumors. It is a smooth muscle tumor that arises from the muscular layer of the esophageal wall. It is usually asymptomatic and may be incidentally discovered on imaging studies or endoscopy. Treatment is usually surgical resection, and the prognosis is excellent.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Most common presentation of gastrinoma/ZES:March 2013 (f, h) Options: A) Abdominal pain B) Duodenal ulcer C) Weight loss D) Nausea<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is C) Weight loss.

Gastrinoma, also known as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES), is a rare endocrine tumor that produces excessive amounts of gastrin, leading to hypergastrinemia. The most common presentation of gastrinoma/ZES is weight loss, which is often accompanied by other symptoms such as:

* Abdominal pain (Option A)
* Nausea and vomiting (Option D)
* Diarrhea or steatorrhea
* Recurrent peptic ulcers, including duodenal ulcers (Option B)

The symptoms of ZES are often insidious and may not be specific, making diagnosis challenging. The diagnosis is typically made by measuring serum gastrin levels and performing an upper GI endoscopy with gastric acid secretion testing. Treatment typically involves surgical resection of the tumor and acid-reducing medications.<|eot_id|>

Question: Decrease in the normal basophilia of the nuclear chromatin in a necrotic cell is known as: Options: A) Pyknosis B) Karyolysis C) Karyorrhexis D) Myelin figures<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Karyolysis.

Karyolysis is a term used to describe the degeneration of the nucleus in a cell, characterized by a decrease in the normal basophilia (staining) of the nuclear chromatin. This is often seen in cells that are undergoing necrosis or apoptosis.

Pyknosis is a term used to describe the condensation of the chromatin in the nucleus, resulting in a dense, dark-staining nucleus.

Karyorrhexis is a term used to describe the fragmentation of the nucleus into small, irregular pieces.

Myelin figures are not related to nuclear changes, but rather are a type of cellular degeneration characterized by the formation of whorls or rings of membranous material within the cytoplasm.<|eot_id|>

Question: Ig active in type 1 hypersensitivity. Options: A) A B) E C) D D) G<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is A) IgE.

IgE is the primary antibody involved in type I hypersensitivity reactions, also known as allergic reactions. IgE is produced in response to the presence of allergens, such as pollen, dust mites, or certain foods, and binds to mast cells and basophils, leading to the release of histamine and other chemical mediators. This causes symptoms such as itching, hives, and anaphylaxis.

IgA, IgD, and IgG are involved in other types of immune responses, but not in type I hypersensitivity reactions.

IgA is involved in mucosal immunity and is found in mucosal secretions, such as saliva, tears, and mucus. It helps to neutralize pathogens and toxins in the mucous membranes.

IgD is an antibody that helps to activate B cells and is involved in the early stages of the immune response.

IgG is a general antibody that is involved in the humoral immune response and provides long-term immunity against infections.<|eot_id|>

Question: Raji cell assay are used to quantitate- Options: A) Complement levels B) Immune complexes C) T- cells D) IFN levels<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Immune complexes.

The Raji cell assay is a test used to measure the levels of immune complexes in the blood. It is a radioimmunoassay that uses Raji cells, a type of human B-cell lymphoma cell line, as the target cells. The assay measures the binding of immune complexes to the Raji cells, which is proportional to the amount of immune complexes present in the sample.

Immune complexes are aggregates of antibodies and antigens that form in response to an immune response. They can be found in the blood and other bodily fluids and can be a sign of various autoimmune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, and vasculitis.

The other options are not correct because:

A) Complement levels are measured using a different assay, such as the CH50 assay.

C) T-cells are measured using a different assay, such as the CD4/CD8 ratio.

D) IFN levels are measured using a different assay, such as ELISA or Western blot.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Type II hypersensitivity is mediated by - Options: A) Complimented mediated B) Antibody mediated C) Immune complex mediated D) Cell mediated<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Antibody mediated.

Type II hypersensitivity is a type of immune response that occurs when an individual's immune system produces antibodies against a specific antigen, such as a protein or a cell surface receptor. This can lead to the activation of complement and the destruction of the target cells.

In type II hypersensitivity, the immune response is mediated by:

* Antibodies (IgG and IgM) that bind to the antigen on the surface of the target cells
* Complement proteins that are activated by the antibody-antigen complex, leading to the destruction of the target cells

Examples of type II hypersensitivity reactions include:

* Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (antibodies against red blood cells)
* Pernicious anemia (antibodies against parietal cells in the stomach)
* Graves' disease (antibodies against thyroid cells)
* Myasthenia gravis (antibodies against acetylcholine receptors)

The other options are not correct:

* Complement-mediated hypersensitivity is a type of immediate hypersensitivity reaction that occurs when an individual's immune system releases histamine and other chemical mediators in response to an allergen.
* Cell-mediated hypersensitivity is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction that occurs when an individual's immune system recognizes an antigen and activates T-cells to attack the antigen-presenting cells.
* Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity is a type of type III hypersensitivity reaction that occurs when an individual's immune system produces immune complexes that deposit in the tissues, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.<|eot_id|>

Question: The amino acid which is associated with atherosclerosis is: Options: A) Lysine B) Homocysteine C) Cysteine D) Alanine<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Homocysteine.

Homocysteine is an amino acid that has been linked to an increased risk of atherosclerosis, a condition characterized by the buildup of plaque in the arteries. Elevated homocysteine levels in the blood have been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, including heart attacks, strokes, and peripheral artery disease.

Lysine is an essential amino acid that is important for collagen synthesis and is not directly associated with atherosclerosis.

Cysteine is another amino acid that is important for the synthesis of glutathione, a antioxidant that helps protect against oxidative stress. While cysteine is important for overall health, it is not directly linked to atherosclerosis.

Alanine is a non-essential amino acid that is involved in the metabolism of other amino acids and is not directly associated with atherosclerosis.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Homocysteine.<|eot_id|>

Question: Which of the following is not a myeloproliferative disease? Options: A) Polycythemia vers B) Acute myeloid leukemia C) Chronic myeloid leukemia D) Essential thrombocytosis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Acute myeloid leukemia.

Myeloproliferative diseases are a group of disorders characterized by the abnormal proliferation of bone marrow cells, leading to an overproduction of blood cells. The options A, C, and D are all examples of myeloproliferative diseases:

* Polycythemia vera (A) is a condition characterized by an overproduction of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.
* Chronic myeloid leukemia (C) is a type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, characterized by the overproduction of white blood cells.
* Essential thrombocytosis (D) is a condition characterized by an overproduction of platelets.

Acute myeloid leukemia (B), on the other hand, is a type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, characterized by the rapid proliferation of abnormal white blood cells. It is not a myeloproliferative disease, as it is not characterized by a chronic and gradual increase in blood cell production. Instead, it is a rapidly progressive and life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical attention.<|eot_id|>

Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Nearly 20% of normal tensile strength of tissue at the site of wound is gained after: September 2008 Options: A) 1 week of wound healing B) 2 weeks of wound healing C) 3 weeks of wound healing D) 4 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Ans. C: 3 weeks of wound healing When tissue is damaged, platelets adhere to exposed matrix integrins that bind to collagen and laminin. Blood coagulation produces thrombin, which promotes platelet aggregation and granule release. The platelet granules generate an inflammatory response. White blood cells are attracted by selections and bind to integrins on endothelial cells, leading to their extravasation through the blood vessel walls. Cytokines released by the white blood cells and platelets up-regulate integrins on macrophages, which migrate to the area of injury, and on fibroblasts and epithelial cells, which mediate wound healing and scar formation. Plasmin aids healing by removing excess fibrin. This aids the migration of keratinocytes into the wound to restore the epithelium under the scab. Collagen proliferates, producing the scar. Wounds gain 20% of their ultimate strength in 3 weeks and later gain more strength, but they never reach more than about 70% of the strength of normal skin. Therefore, the correct answer is C) 3 weeks of wound healing<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: A 38-year-old woman has been feeling lethargic for 4 months. On physical examination, she is afebrile, and her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Laboratory findings show the serum creatinine level is 5.8 mg/dL. C3 nephritic factor is present in serum, resulting in hypocomplementemia, and the ANA test result is negative. Urinalysis shows 2+ blood and 1+ protein. A renal biopsy is done; microscopic examination shows hypercellular glomeruli and prominent ribbonlike deposits along the lamina densa of the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following forms of glomerulonephritis is most likely to be present in this patient? Options: A) Chronic glomerulonephritis B) Dense deposit disease C) Membranous nephropathy D) Postinfectious glomerulonephritis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Dense deposit disease.

Dense deposit disease, also known as type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, is a type of glomerulonephritis characterized by the presence of dense deposits in the glomerular basement membrane. These deposits are composed of immune complexes, primarily composed of IgG and C3, which are deposited along the lamina densa of the glomerular basement membrane. The deposits can cause inflammation and damage to the glomerular basement membrane, leading to proteinuria, hematuria, and nephritic syndrome.

The presence of C3 nephritic factor in the patient's serum, which is an autoantibody that binds to C3 convertase and prevents the breakdown of C3, is consistent with the diagnosis of dense deposit disease.

The other options are not consistent with the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings:

* Chronic glomerulonephritis is a type of glomerulonephritis that occurs as a result of chronic inflammation and scarring of the glomeruli, which is not consistent with the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings.
* Membranous nephropathy is a type of glomerulonephritis characterized by the deposition of immune complexes in the glomerular basement membrane, but it is not typically associated with the presence of C3 nephritic factor.
* Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is a type of glomerulonephritis that occurs as a result of an immune response to a previous infection, typically streptococcal infection, and is not typically associated with the presence of C3 nephritic factor.<|eot_id|>

Question: Fundoscopy of an HIV infected patient shows Pizza Pie Appearance, An Upper GI endoscopy biopsy specimen of the same patient for dysphagia shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis? Options: A) Candidiasis B) Herpes C) CMV D) Eosinophilic Esophagitis<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Virus Inclusion Description Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Cowdry type A Intranuclear Basophilic (or Amphophilic) inclusions surrounded by a halo and by marginated chromatin Intracytoplasmic Inclusions consists of clusters of small granular basophilic bodies of various sizes Ref: Harrison&;s 19th edition Pgno: 1191 Therefore, the correct answer is C) CMV<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. HSV esophagitis: Esophagus is the most common site of GI herpes infection. HSV infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, including those with underlying lymphoma, leukemia and AIDS, transplant recipients and burn victims. It commonly involves the middle and distal thirds of the esophagus. Microscopically, the characteristic feature of herpetic infection occur in the squamous epithelium at the margin of the ulcers or erosions. The 2 types of viral inclusions present in HSV infection are: homogenous or smudge cells and acidophilic inclusions with a surrounding clear halo and peripheral chromatin migration(Cowdry type A). Ref: Morson and Dawson's Gastrointestinal Pathology edited by Neil A. Shepherd, page 27. Therefore, the correct answer is A) Edge of ulcer<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>

Question: Testis determining gene/sex determining region is located on: Options: A) X chromosome B) Y chromosome C) Chromosome 21 D) Chromosome 18<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The correct answer is B) Y chromosome.

The testis-determining gene, also known as SRY (Sex-Determining Region Y), is located on the short arm of the Y chromosome (Yp). It is responsible for triggering the development of testes in the embryo and is a critical factor in determining the development of male characteristics.

In humans, the presence of an SRY gene on the Y chromosome leads to the development of testes, while the absence of SRY or the presence of a different gene on the X chromosome leads to the development of ovaries. This is why individuals with a Y chromosome are typically male, while those with an X chromosome are typically female.

The other options are incorrect because:

* X chromosome (Option A) is the sex chromosome that carries the genes that determine the development of ovaries and female characteristics.
* Chromosome 21 (Option C) is one of the 23 pairs of autosomal chromosomes that do not play a direct role in sex determination.
* Chromosome 18 (Option D) is also an autosomal chromosome that is not involved in sex determination.<|eot_id|>

Question: A 15-year-old boy presented with one day history of bleedig gums, subconjunctival bleed and purpuric rash. Investigations revealed the following results:Hb-6.4 gm/dL; TLC-26,500/mm3 Platelet 35,000 mm3; prothrombin time-20 sec with a control of 13 sec; paial thromboplastin time-50sec; and Fibrinogen 10mg/dL. Peripheral smear was suggestive of acute myeloblastic leukemia. Which of the following is the most likely - Options: A) Myeloblastic leukemia without maturation B) Myeloblastic leukemia with maturation C) Promyelocytic leukemia D) Myelomonocytic leukemia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which is a common complication of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The patient's low platelet count, prolonged prothrombin time, and low fibrinogen level are all consistent with DIC.

APL is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that is characterized by a specific chromosomal translocation, t(15;17), which results in the fusion of the promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene and the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene. This fusion gene produces a chimeric protein that inhibits the differentiation of myeloid cells, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow.

The patient's peripheral blood smear is likely to show a high percentage of blasts, which are immature myeloid cells that are not yet fully differentiated. The blasts may be myeloblasts, promyeloblasts, or other immature myeloid cells.

Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is:

C) Promyelocytic leukemia<|eot_id|>

Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests probable diagnosis of CMV Retinitis. The Histolpathological slide from the Upper GI Endoscopy biospy specimen shows presence of large (cytomegalic) cells with Owl&;s eye appearance. This appearance is typical of CMV infection. Pizza Pie Appearance of Retina on fundoscopy in an HIV infected patient suggests CMV Cytomegalovirus retinitis is the single most common oppounistic ocular infection seen in immunocompromised patients including those affected with HIV CMV retinitis in HIV patients is characterized by haemorrhage and necrosis in a perivascular distribution, with loss of fundal details, giving it the classical &;Pizza Pie&; Appearance This appearance is also termed as "Cheese and ketchup" appearance. Owl&;s eye Appearance from Intranuclear Inclusions in Biopsy Specimen suggests CMV infection Cells infected with CMV are two to four times larger than surrounding cells (cytomegalic) in vivo and often contain an 8- to 10- micromts intranuclear basophilic (or amphophilic ) inclusion body that is eccentrically placed and is surrounded by a clear peripheral halo, producing an "owl eye" appearance (sometimes called Bull&;s eye appearance) Smaller inclusions may also be demostrated in the cytoplasm occasionally (Typically basophillic and smaller) Cytomegalic cells are found in a wide variety of organs, including the salivary glands, lung, liver, kidney, intestine, pancreas, adrenal gland and central nervous system. Question: Which is the BEST site for taking biopsy in a case of viral oesophagitis? Options: A) Edge of ulcer B) Base of ulcer C) Adjacent indurated area around ulcer D) Surrounding normal mucosa<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The best place to take biopsy is from within the the squamous mucosa at the edges of the ulcer and in sloughed cells within the exudate. Question: A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at age 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 mm3; platelet count, 277,400/ mm3; and WBC count, 5920/ mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis? Options: A) Disseminated intravascular coagulation B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D) Vitamin C deficiency<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with defective platelet aggregation from deficiency or dysfunction of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. The platelet aggregation studies described here are characteristic of this disorder. Disseminated intravascular coagulation results in the consumption of all coagulation factors and platelets, so the prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time are elevated with thrombocytopenia. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by antibodies to platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb/IIIa or Ib/IX. Scurvy resulting from vitamin C deficiency causes bleeding into soft tissues and skin from increased capillary fragility, but platelet number and function are normal. Von Willebrand disease is one of the most common bleeding disorders and results from qualitative or quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor. Therefore, the correct answer is B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>user<|end_header_id|>
